The basis of globalization is based the theory of comparative advantage. Comparative advantage allow each country to concentrate on those activities (such as manufacturing and services) they are most profitable for them compared to their other activities. Thus every country benefits from globalization regardless of how competitive they may be. For example, take the US and Bangladesh. The US is more efficient at both manufacturing and services than Bangladesh, but services is more profitable for the US. Thus it makes sense for the US to concentrate most of its efforts on the more profitable service industry rather than manufacturing. Manufacturing is thus left to other countries, like Bangladesh, even if it is less efficient at it than the US. Bangladesh chooses manufacturing than services, because it is more profitable for the country (because of cheap labour) than services. This is why that high tech service company is based in the US, and why your clothes are made in Bangladesh these days. So globalization does allow for more opportunities at the country level, but it is also opportunistic because countries sacrifice entire industry sectors to maximize their profits, thus hurting those workers in the abandoned sectors.

Originally the term was exclusively used to mean the nature of something, that is its inborn (or innate) characteristics. Then along came propositions like “A gas expands to fill the space available to it”. Because in doing so a gas was said to be obeying the dictates or laws of its own nature, the word was given a capital letter, Nature, as if it was some realm with its own laws mirroring human polities with theirs. Science was now considered the study of this realm.
